citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 7 week old male Lhaso Apso puppy (id# 2459, DOB 5/10/2024, white and brown) was observed to be lethargic and
unwilling to move. The puppy was the only one in the litter but the other litters of puppies in the next enclosures at
approximately the same age were very active. He did not try to move when the mom was jumping around and on him.
When removed from the enclosure and placed on the floor, it still was not willing to move and showed no interest. No
diarrhea was observed. The owner had not been to the kennel yet on this day and the helper had not reported anything
abnormal about this dog. Due to how quickly puppies can decline if not given proper medical care, this puppy must be
evaluated by a veterinarian for diagnosis and treatment by end of this day.
To be corrected by close of business on 6/24/2024
A female white Poodle (Roseanna, id# 6312, DOB 5/14/2018) appeared thin. There was an abdominal tuck and the ribs
and hips were easily palpated. Her molars were encased in a large amount of brown hard material making it difficult to
determine each separate tooth. Poor dental health is painful to the dog and can lead to further health issues, including
weight loss. Poor body condition can be the result of parasites, inadequate nutrition, or an underlying medical condition,
such as dental disease. The condition had not been observed by the licensee. The licensee must use appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries in the regulated animals and ensure each animal
receives adequate veterinary care at all times. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to
assess its health and to develop an effective treatment plan. Medical records must be maintained on both dogs and made
available to APHIS inspection.
TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 28, 2024
NOTE: Licensee understood that the Lhaso Apso puppy needed to be evaluated by a veterinarian and called the
veterinarian to get an appointment for that day (6/24/2024).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 7 week old male Lhaso Apso puppy (id# 2459, DOB 5/10/2024, white and brown) was observed to be lethargic and 
unwilling to move. The puppy was the only one in the litter but the other litters of puppies in the next enclosures at 
approximately the same age were very active. He did not try to move when the mom was jumping around and on him. 
When removed from the enclosure and placed on the floor, it still was not willing to move and showed no interest. No 
diarrhea was observed. The owner had not been to the kennel yet on this day and the helper had not reported anything 
abnormal about this dog. Due to how quickly puppies can decline if not given proper medical care, this puppy must be 
evaluated by a veterinarian for diagnosis and treatment by end of this day.  
To be corrected by close of business on 6/24/2024 
 
A female white Poodle (Roseanna, id# 6312, DOB 5/14/2018) appeared thin. There was an abdominal tuck and the ribs 
and hips were easily palpated. Her molars were encased in a large amount of brown hard material making it difficult to 
determine each separate tooth. Poor dental health is painful to the dog and can lead to further health issues, including 
weight loss. Poor body condition can be the result of parasites, inadequate nutrition, or an underlying medical condition, 
such as dental disease. The condition had not been observed by the licensee. The licensee must use appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries in the regulated animals and ensure each animal 
receives adequate veterinary care at all times. The licensee must have this dog evaluated by a licensed veterinarian to 
assess its health and to develop an effective treatment plan. Medical records must be maintained on both dogs and made 
available to APHIS inspection.  
 TO BE CORRECTED BY JUNE 28, 2024 
 
NOTE: Licensee understood that the Lhaso Apso puppy needed to be evaluated by a veterinarian and called the 
veterinarian to get an appointment for that day (6/24/2024). 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
